Astride a grisly one-ey'd stallion</br>Sat FELT — the Chief of our Battalion,</br>Resolv'd each buckish head to spatter,</br>(The Patriot Felt's by trade a Hatter).</br>A TALLOW-CHANDLER, much perplext</br>To guide his poney, canter'd next;</br>Stuck like a candle in his socket;</br>A Major's brevet in his pocket.</br>Next mov'd on, slow, four Pioneers,</br>With caps that screen'd their gentle ears:</br>Deaf to all time, or drum, they went,</br>And look'd as if on ill intent:</br>Two COOKS, two POTTERS, men of weight,</br>Who seem'd the Pillars of the State.</br>Behind these wind-screens, silly plac'd,</br>Was CROTCH:  white-gloves his fingers grac'd;</br>A peaceful sabre tight he grasp'd,</br>And eye'd the Ladies as they pass'd;</br>Pointing the toe in due position,</br>As should a well-bred old Musician:</br>He swears an oath, looks up, and sneers,</br>And cries, "March on, my Grenadiers!—"</br>COUTURE, his Serjeant, was a Tailor,</br>The son of MANACLE the Jailor,</br>The fairest of this warlike groupe,</br>And drest the best of all the troop,</br>Save TUE-VITAE, who was quite the thing,</br>Fam'd Bug-destroyer to the King;</br>His feather'd cap he proudly tost,</br>And took, as Corp'ral, next, his post.</br>The other Grenadiers were Sweepers,</br>Toymen, Lamp-Lighters, Alehouse-Keepers,</br>Men-Milliners, and Breeches-Makers,</br>And, last of all, two Undertakers.</br>The Captain of the centre was</br>GENCIVE, Quack Dentist, bold as brass:</br>His Ensign was a dangerous blade;</br>A man of blood he was by trade,</br>A very sure and quick dispatcher,</br>A Faculty-approv'd Rat-Catcher;</br>His waistcoat was so lin'd with ermine,</br>You'd thought him 'mongst his friends, the vermin.</br>A Bard whose coat was sadly torn,</br>The Patriot Standard did adorn,</br>And held it so above the throng,</br>He broke the windows all along;</br>'Twas an agreement with a Glazier,</br>Who follow'd with AIRAIN the Brazier.—</br>A crack-brain'd Surgeon, Serjeant-Major,</br>Clos'd up the rear, as for a wager:</br>So quick he stepp'd that none could match him,</br>For e'en his Captain could not catch him.

Yet Young Light-Infantry came on</br>In order due, the rear-upon,</br>Led by COCHON the Bacon-man,</br>Of eighteen-stone weight. — PATTY PAN,</br>The Pastry-Cook, was one stone lighter,</br>And in his gaiters somewhat tighter.</br>All those who after them took place,</br>Were most a horrid crippled race;</br>Their Officers were all Shoe-Makers,</br>Corn-Doctors, Hosiers, lusty Bakers,</br>Who (since each now on interest goes),</br>Oppress'd the bellies, or the toes.

All these were rang'd beneath the banners</br>Of PATRIOTISM — in different manners:</br>Some march'd, some limp'd, and some did run</br>By couples — others, one by one:</br>To drink, pick pockets, or to swear;</br>But all, with pious resolution,</br>To ratify the CONSTITUTION.</br>They did — with loud huzzas, and shouts,</br>With folly, and with revel routs:</br>They drank till they their reason lost,</br>But all to Patriotic Toast;—</br>Such as — "Let's knock all order down,</br>Despoil the Church, and rob the Crown."</br>LOUIS came too, to see them dance,</br>And signed "DESTRUCTION TO ALL FRANCE!"</br>
